artist: Tsukioka Yoshitoshi; Publisher: Akiyama Buemon; Carver: Wada Yūjirō
creditline: The Mary Griggs Burke Endowment Fund established by the Mary Livingston Griggs and Mary Griggs Burke Foundation, gifts of various donors, by exchange, and gift of Edmond Freis in memory of his parents, Rose and Leon Freis
markings: Artist’s seal: 大蘇 {Taiso} | Carver’s seal: 彫勇 {hori Yū}
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e), ink and color on paper
portfolio: The Snow, Moon, and Flowers (Setsugekka no uchi 雪月花乃内)
text: The Kabuki actor Ichikawa Danjūrō IX (1838–1903) is portrayed as Kezori Kuemon, a real smuggler who became the subject of puppet and Kabuki plays. Kezori is the captain of a Japanese pirate ship and typically wears a Chinese-inspired costume decorated with dragons and jewels. He is depicted here in the moonlight waiting for a boat with illicit goods. Yoshitoshi emphasizes his power by setting his extravagant appearance on a plain background alongside a simple moon disk.
title: Moon: Actor Ichikawa Sanshō as Kezori Kuemon
